s0001: Prince Xiao of Liang, Liu Wu, was a son of Emperor Xiaowen, and shared the same mother as Emperor Xiaojing.
s0002: Their mother was Empress Dowager Dou.
s0003: Emperor Xiaowen had four sons altogether: the eldest son was the Crown Prince, who became Emperor Xiaojing;
s0007: Emperor Xiaowen ascended the throne in year 2, enfeoffing Wu as King of Dai, Shen as King of Taiyuan, Sheng as King of Liang.
s0008: Two years later, he transferred the King of Dai to be King of Huaiyang.
s0009: He gave all of Dai to the King of Taiyuan, who was then titled King of Dai.
s0010: Shen reigned seventeen years, died in the second year after Xiaowen, posthumous title King Xiao.
s0011: His son Deng succeeded him, becoming King Gong of Dai.
s0012: He reigned twenty-nine years, died in Yuanguang year 2.
s0013: His son Yi succeeded him, becoming King of Dai.
s0014: Nineteen years later, Han expanded the passes, using Changshan as the boundary, and transferred the King of Dai to rule Qinghe.
s0015: The King of Qinghe's transfer was in Yuanding year 3.
s0016: Initially, Wu served as King of Huaiyang for ten years, while the King of Liang Sheng died, posthumous title King Huai of Liang.
s0017: King Huai was the youngest son, loved and favored differently from the other sons.
s0018: The next year, he transferred the King of Huaiyang Wu to be King of Liang.
s0019: The King of Liang's first enfeoffment in Liang was in Emperor Xiaowen's twelfth year.
s0020: The King of Liang, from his initial enfeoffment to now, had experienced eleven years.
s0021: In the King of Liang's fourteenth year, he entered court.
s0022: In years seventeen and eighteen, he entered court consecutively, remained, and only the next year returned to his fief.
s0023: In year twenty-one, he entered court.
s0024: In year twenty-two, Emperor Xiaowen passed away.
s0025: In year twenty-four, he entered court.
s0026: In year twenty-five, he entered court again.
s0027: At this time the emperor had not yet established a crown prince.
s0028: The emperor and the King of Liang were feasting, and once casually said: 'After a thousand autumns and ten thousand years I will pass it to the king.'
s0030: Though he knew these were not serious words, in his heart he was inwardly pleased.
s0031: The empress dowager was the same.
s0032: That spring, Wu, Chu, Qi, and Zhao—the seven kingdoms—rebelled.
s0033: Wu and Chu first attacked Liang's Ji Wall, killing tens of thousands.
s0034: Prince Xiao of Liang defended the city of Suiyang, and sent Han Anguo, Zhang Yu and others as grand generals to resist Wu and Chu.
s0035: Wu and Chu used Liang as their limit, dared not cross west, and confronted Grand Commandant Yafu and others for three months.
s0036: Wu and Chu were defeated, and Liang's captured, killed, and plundered was shared equally with Han.
s0037: The next year, Han established the crown prince.
s0038: Afterwards Liang was closest, had merit, was also a great kingdom, occupying the fertile lands of the realm.
s0039: Its territory bordered Mount Tai in the north, reached Gaoyang in the west, over forty cities, all with many large counties.
s0040: Prince Xiao was Empress Dowager Dou's youngest son, she loved him, rewards and grants beyond counting.
s0041: Thus Prince Xiao built the Eastern Park, covering over three hundred li square.
s0042: He expanded Suiyang city seventy li.
s0043: He greatly constructed palaces, built covered walkways connecting from the palace to the Platform for over thirty li.
s0044: He received the emperor's banners and flags as grants, went out followed by a thousand chariots and ten thousand cavalry.
s0045: He galloped hunting east and west, comparable to the Son of Heaven.
s0046: When going out he used 'clear the way,' when entering he used 'be alert.'
s0047: He recruited and welcomed heroes and outstanding men from the four directions, wandering persuaders from east of the mountains.
s0048: None failed to arrive completely—men from Qi like Yang Sheng, Gongsun Gui, Zou Yang and such.
s0049: Gongsun Gui had many strange and crooked schemes, first meeting the king, granted a thousand jin, office reaching Commandant of the Guards, Liang titled him General Gongsun, Liang made many weapons—crossbows, bows, spears—several tens of thousands, while the treasury had gold and cash nearly a hundred million, pearls, jade, and precious objects more than the capital.
s0050: In year twenty-nine, tenth month, Prince Xiao of Liang entered court.
